context: [8] This amount would be the administered dose for a person who consumed 2 liters of water containing 35 ppb TCE in one sitting. [9] People normally consume water in divided doses, circumstances under which the liver is even more efficient in removing TCE. [1] Although the liver and lungs offer extrahepatic organs protection from ingested TCE, potentially toxic metabolites formed in the liver may be released into the systemic circulation. [2] TCE is biotransformed primarily via a CYP450-catalyzed pathway involving sequential formation of a series of metabolites including chloral, chloral hydrate, trichloroacetic acid, possibly dichloroacetic acid, and trichloroethanol . [3] Chloral hydrate, trichloroacetic acid, and dichloroacetic acid have been implicated in rodent liver carcinogenesis, although apparently not in adverse effects in other organs . [4] The second, relatively minor TCE biotransformation pathway involves glutathione conjugation and subsequent conversion to a series of products . [5] Certain metabolites enter the blood and bile, from which they may reenter the liver to be detoxified or be taken up by the kidney cells and undergo metabolic activation to cytotoxic, mutagenic moieties .
